utterance: JM: Calculate this reorganization energy and all these other parameters that he goes into theory and he said, I never did, right? So he never really calculate all these numbers that he uses his theory and he was saying, well, I only took it from the experiments and I put it on my theory and the only trick that he did is, you know, he he just reorganized entire equations that he have, you know, half a page of equation into something that is simple, but it just get parameters from experiments. So the lessons I guess from that one when I when I ask him he said, well, this model work really well, but he never actually calculate anything from, you know, from those organization energies and all these salvation things. So I was wondering, it's extremely useful and is certainly a model system that it's approximate more things. So I don't know if um, you know, we're talking about very um a more accurate simulations with realistic stuff and also very simplistic models that can probably do more accurate and and and efficient. I was wondering because that electron transfer theory, it actually is in the middle ground, right? It's complexity but also a model system. So but it's so successful and explaining many things. So maybe also the two extremes are good, but maybe we can also think in something in the middle just like the lesson we learned from from electron transfer um uh with the Marcus theory.

annotations.explain or define term or concept: JM explains that the researcher he spoke with simplified complex equations by using parameters derived from experiments, not calculations.

utterance: FL: Jump in and say something. So, um I think that there were a lot of discussions here already about the electro electro interface. Uh one thing that's not covered in the topic is the concentration gradient at the at the surface layer. The electrical double layer is one thing, but that layer is very small. But if you are talking about uh uh the concentration gradient layer uh applying to the equals system that could be the pH gradient at the surface. That can range from uh few nanometers to tens of microns, even 100 microns. There are a lot of things going on in there, the dissolution of the catalyst and different solvation structure of the catalyst and um and the cluster formation in the solution phase and how that cluster will dissolve and re-deposit back to the electro surface. There's a lot of things in that gradient layer that's completely unknown at this point. So, um we have been doing research uh developing uh mostly based on single term techniques to to visualize the specially uh spatial resolution and with temporal resolution as well at that gradient uh layer, what what's going on with the metal ions in that layer. Uh can range from uh protons, hydroxidions and metal ions dissolve from the from the electrodes and uh there's a lot of things who can can be done at that interface to to to modify the surface of the catalyst.

annotations.explain or define term or concept: FL explains the concept of the concentration gradient layer, differentiating it from the electrical double layer and highlighting its relevance to pH gradients and metal ion behavior.

utterance: SB: Sharma, you any thoughts?

annotations.encourage participation: SB asks Sharma for his thoughts, inviting him to contribute to the ongoing discussion.

utterance: SM: I think just that like from from like an electrochemical interface, right? The way the whole field of development has evolved is that you have this artificial divide between quantum chemist and quantum physicist. Like quantum chemist work on these idealized gas phase systems and physicist work on these continuous systems. So no one bothered to benchmark things to the interface. So I think even the gas solid interface is a challenging thing for us to model, let alone a gas liquid interface. So I think there is some progress in figuring out like what these benchmark systems might be through like these single crystal uh experiments so to speak, which allow for us to at least look at how things bind at that interface and how our theories perform. So I I think electrochemistry electrochemical interfaces is a whole other ball game altogether, although I don't know much about them. Um but yeah, model systems, I think even for a gas solid interface is quite a challenge and any progress in that would be amazing. Um yeah, and the other issue of course is that all of these things are dynamic. So one way around it for defining a model system would be to try and pick out those catalysts that have uniform active sites. So in part of my group gets away with it because we look at molecular catalyst, but when it comes to interfaces, there's there's we have to look at the ensemble. And even if we do look at the ensemble, we still don't know how to get it up to experiments. So we are trying to do dynamics, but then dynamics again, there's so little you can do with initial dynamics. You can't really simulate realistic time scales. So trying to figure out if there are like picosecond time scale experiments that we can actually benchmark the theory and and then take it forward from there might might also be a way forward.

annotations.explain or define term or concept: SM explains that the field has developed with an artificial divide between quantum chemists who work on idealized gas phase systems and quantum physicists who work on continuous systems, making benchmarking at the interface difficult.
annotations.provide supporting evidence: SM supports the challenge of gas-solid interface modeling by mentioning the lack of benchmarking against interfaces and the dynamic nature of these systems.
annotations.present new idea: SM proposes focusing on catalysts with uniform active sites as a way to define a model system for dynamic interfaces.
annotations.expand on existing idea: SM expands on the challenges of electrochemical interfaces by highlighting the difficulty of modeling gas-solid and gas-liquid interfaces and the limitations of current dynamics simulations.
annotations.offer constructive criticism: SM critiques the current approach to modeling electrochemical interfaces, pointing out the limitations of initial dynamics simulations in capturing realistic timescales.

utterance: EN: Oh, just quickly I was going to say, so so my group is really interested in building um electro catalyst, molecular electro catalyst based on porphrin scaffolds. Um and I'm also interested in uh in in doing time resolved infrared spectroscopy. So I think I would be certainly really excited to uh try to collaborate with theorists uh on on that and maybe starting even from something really simple like um you know, substrate binding studies that don't even have to progress beyond or or that initially would not progress uh into the realm of catalysis, but could just look at what's the role of the local environment and how can we build models to address that question.

utterance: SS: I feel like theory is highly underutilized in that domain. So where theory has come about is as a way of validating experiments, right? And at least as far as catalysis goes, experiments mostly go after finding the most active catalyst, which is great, but then that doesn't look at the other aspects, right? Like is the catalyst stable? Is it selective and so on? I think theory has a way to take into account all of these inherent trade-offs and come up with some sort of an integrated design strategy. And and there's there's a lot that can be done there. It's just I think it's only now taking off.

annotations.present new idea: "An integrated design strategy" is introduced by combining theory and experimental considerations for catalyst design, going beyond just activity.
annotations.provide supporting evidence: The speaker supports the idea of theory's underutilization by pointing out that experiments primarily focus on catalyst activity, neglecting other crucial aspects like stability and selectivity.
annotations.expand on existing idea: The speaker expands on the limitations of current experimental approaches in catalysis by highlighting their focus on activity and the neglect of other important factors.
annotations.offer constructive criticism: The speaker critiques the current state of catalysis research by highlighting the underutilization of theory and the limited scope of experimental approaches.
annotations.express enthusiasm: The speaker expresses optimism about the potential of theory to contribute to an integrated design strategy in catalysis, suggesting it is "taking off".

So, um, I don't know, I just wonder because there's these all these experiments, especially for synthesis that you can tell, you know, what temperature doesn't work or what solvent doesn't work or something.
